isis.stitle: TSI 96-08-04 - Operation of the Hall Effect Stop Light and Brake Booster Pump Switch

subjectgroup.subject: Operation of the Hall Effect Stop Light and Brake Booster Pump Switch

geninfo.para: This TSI applies to the 3000RE bus with hydraulic brakes.

As a result of the release of the new 3000RE bus with hydraulic brakes, Navistar has incorporated a Hall Effect stop light and brake booster pump switch. The Hall Effect switch is an electronic device which generates a voltage signal controlled by the presence, absence or strength of a magnetic field ( Figure 1). This switch is located under the floor at the brake pedal.

When the pedal mounted magnet is moved away from the switch, the switch closes and the switched circuit goes to ground. When the Hall Effect switch goes to ground, both stop light relays are then grounded and the relays close. Refer to the circuit diagram ( Figure 2).

svcproc.title: PROPER HYDRAULIC BRAKE SYSTEM ELECTRICAL OPERATION

item.para: With Ignition OFF and Brake Pedal Not Applied
Brake booster pump must be OFF
With Ignition OFF and Brake Pedal Applied (Light Pressure)
With Ignition ON - Engine Not Running - Brake Pedal Not Applied
Brake lights must NOT BE ON
Brake booster pump must RUN with warning lamp and buzzer ON
With Engine Running and Pedal Not Applied
Brake lights must NOT BE ON
Brake booster pump, warning lamp and buzzer must NOT BE ON
With Engine Running and Brake Pedal Applied
Brake booster pump, warning lamp and buzzer must NOT BE ON unless there is a fault in the brake or power steering hydraulic system.

svcproc.title: DIAGNOSTICS
svcproc.para: If the brake system does not operate as described above, the Hall Effect switch may be out of adjustment. With the brake pedal released, the air gap between the end of the switch and the magnet should be .100 to .200 inch. Adjustment may be made by backing off the lock nut and screwing the switch in or out as required to get the proper air gap. With key OFF, brake booster pump motor must come on with light foot pressure; make appropriate adjustment.

To determine if the Hall Effect switch is defective, do the following: Refer to circuit diagram ( Figure 2). Disconnect connector 209 and check voltage at terminal "A" of harness side of connector. If there is no voltage at terminal "A," check wiring and fuse. At pin "C," insure that the circuit goes to ground. Check "B" to insure that there is voltage present; if not, check relays, wiring and fuses. Ground "B," pump must come on. If pump does not come on, check relay, wiring and pump.

Reconnect connector 209. With magnet away from switch face (more than .200 inch), pump must be on. With magnet brought close to Hall Effect switch (.100 inch or less), pump must not be on. If the above does not occur, replace Hall Effect switch.
For complete electrical diagnostic procedures for the hydraulic brake system, refer to CTS-5190 in the CTS-5000 Master Service Manual.
